reason: Nathan Goldbaum will be resubmitting my particle_fields.py changes along with additional changes in a new PR
description:
With the help of @ngoldbaum I managed to hack together a particle_cylindrical_r and particle_cylindrical_z fields.

I noticed that these fields were missing, and I need them for some data analysis. So I wish to add these fields into YT.

EDIT... getting values that are too large at this moment in time.

UPDATE: values should now be relative to the center of each data object

will add particle_cylindrical_theta and the polar coord units... at some point.. just really needed r and z for now
title: [WIP] particle_cylindrical_r and particle_cylindrical_z fields added

content.raw:
I think this is good, but I think that the field names should be modified to fit the standard of the spherical coordinate field names:


```
#!python

(‘all’, ‘particle_spherical_position_phi’)
(‘all’, ‘particle_spherical_position_radius’)
(‘all’, ‘particle_spherical_position_theta’)
(‘all’, ‘particle_spherical_velocity_phi’)
(‘all’, ‘particle_spherical_velocity_radius’)
(‘all’, ‘particle_spherical_velocity_theta’)
```


So perhaps instead of setting the fields as `particle_cylindrical_r`, it should be `particle_cylindrical_position_radius` and so on?
content.html:
I think this is good, but I think that the field names should be modified to fit the standard of the spherical coordinate field names:

(‘all’, ‘particle_spherical_position_phi’)
(‘all’, ‘particle_spherical_position_radius’)
(‘all’, ‘particle_spherical_position_theta’)
(‘all’, ‘particle_spherical_velocity_phi’)
(‘all’, ‘particle_spherical_velocity_radius’)
(‘all’, ‘particle_spherical_velocity_theta’)

So perhaps instead of setting the fields as particle_cylindrical_r, it should be particle_cylindrical_position_radius and so on?

content.raw:
I agree. I initially went for particle_cylindrical_r since I was wanting to match the fluid field ("index","cylindrical_r") ... hence particle_cylindrical_r. But for consistency with the rest of the particle fields I agree with particle_cylindrical_position_radius and particle_cylindrical_velocity_radius.. basically these fields below.

```
#!python


 (‘all’, ‘particle_cylindrical_position_radius')
 (‘all’, ‘particle_cylindrical_position_z’)
 (‘all’, ‘particle_cylindrical_position_theta’)
 (‘all’, ‘particle_cylindrical_velocity_radius’)
 (‘all’, ‘particle_cylindrical_velocity_z)
 (‘all’, ‘particle_cylindrical_velocity_theta’)
```


Not 100% sure about what to do with z ... in the fluids, radius is shortened to r consistently (hence spherical_r appears in fluids.. maybe this should be changed for consistency with particle?) ... so what would make more sense.. particle_cylindrical_position_z or particle_cylindrical_position_height (I personally think particle_cylindrical_position_z )
content.html:

But for consistency with the rest of the particle fields I agree with particle_cylindrical_position_radius and particle_cylindrical_velocity_radius.. basically these fields below.

 (‘all’, ‘particle_cylindrical_position_z’)

 (‘all’, ‘particle_cylindrical_velocity_theta’)

Not 100% sure about what to do with z ... in the fluids, radius is shortened to r consistently (hence spherical_r appears in fluids.. maybe this should be changed for consistency with particle?) ... so what would make more sense.. particle_cylindrical_position_z or particle_cylindrical_position_height (I personally think particle_cylindrical_position_z )

content.raw: FWIW, [YTEP-0003](http://ytep.readthedocs.org/en/latest/YTEPs/YTEP-0003.html) is supposed to be the authoratative resource for field naming.
content.html: FWIW, YTEP-0003 is supposed to be the authoratative resource for field naming.

content.raw:
You're right, I forgot about that.  However, at the time of YTEP-0003, we didn't have spherical particle fields.  And then they got renamed just prior to the release of 3.0 to their current values.

I guess it is somewhat problematic to have the particle fields and fluid fields not using the same format:
spherical_r (for fluids)
particle_spherical_position_radius (for particles)

(and the equivalent in cylindrical now).  In an ideal world, we'd have:

spherical_position_radius (for fluids)
particle_spherical_position_radius (for particles)

or something else that matched, but I'm not sure if we can get sufficient backing to shift these field names, unless we provided backwards compatibility.  Now we have cylindrical in the same game.  What do people think?  

BTW, I'm not suggesting this big field name reshuffle be part of this PR.
content.html:
You're right, I forgot about that. However, at the time of YTEP-0003, we didn't have spherical particle fields. And then they got renamed just prior to the release of 3.0 to their current values.

I guess it is somewhat problematic to have the particle fields and fluid fields not using the same format: spherical_r (for fluids) particle_spherical_position_radius (for particles)

(and the equivalent in cylindrical now). In an ideal world, we'd have:

spherical_position_radius (for fluids) particle_spherical_position_radius (for particles)

or something else that matched, but I'm not sure if we can get sufficient backing to shift these field names, unless we provided backwards compatibility. Now we have cylindrical in the same game. What do people think?

BTW, I'm not suggesting this big field name reshuffle be part of this PR.

content.html: I don't think this PR should be accepted until we iron out the situation with the field naming scheme or else we're going to have diverging and inconsistent field names through yt.

content.raw:
Hey, sorry for not doing much with this PR.

As well as the naming conventions.. by my understanding, all the particle fields should use particle_position_r (e.g particle_cylindrical_position_r ) or am I misinterpreting YTEP-0003 since it sounds like particle_position_radius was added in after YTEP-0003. Likewise I feel particle_cylindrical_position_z  I feel is a bit nicer to type than particle_cylindrical_position_height (i.e less ambiguous). Although we do have a particle_position_z .. so both could work out fine. (but obviously particle_cylindrical_position_z is in the ref frame of the disk)

There is another issue with this PR too, I have noticed that get_sph_r_component in addition to  get_sph_r is used for the particle fields (whereas the gas fields, this is not the case)

e.g

```
#!python

        theta = get_sph_theta(pos, center)
        phi = get_sph_phi(pos, center)
        pos = pos - np.reshape(center, (3, 1))
        spht = get_sph_theta_component(pos, theta, phi, normal)
```
simply looking over this piece of code (without any of the other inner workings. My gut feeling is that I should be doing something like


```
#!python

        theta = get_cyl_theta(pos, center)
        z = get_cyl_z(pos, center)
        pos = pos - np.reshape(center, (3, 1))
        cylr = get_cyl_r_component(pos, theta, normal)
```
whereas in the gas, it just calls


```
#!python


    def _cylindrical_r(field, data):
        normal = data.get_field_parameter("normal")
        coords = get_periodic_rvec(data)
        return data.ds.arr(get_cyl_r(coords, normal), "code_length").in_cgs()

```
Really.. this might also be for another PR... but the fluid geometry transformations seem to auto convert to cgs... really it might be best to leave them in whatever units the vectors were in before get_cyl_r was called.

Also. I intend on going all the way, and including particle_cylindrical_position_theta and the velocity componants.

e.g

        theta = get_sph_theta(pos, center)

content.raw: so should it be cylindrical_position_r or cylindrical_position_radius.. sounds like the latter if the field names were meant to be updated when the particle fields got included.
content.html: so should it be cylindrical_position_r or cylindrical_position_radius.. sounds like the latter if the field names were meant to be updated when the particle fields got included.

content.raw:
Okey I have been having a play around with some of my own data and these new fields

Beforehand, YT has been computing the radius and height in slightly different ways for particles and fluids in spherical and cylindrical systems. 

YT has just been computing the *magnitude* of the radius and the height in the gas, whilst plotting the radius and the height with respect to the origin and normal vector for the particle fields.

The new suggested changes below means we can access both the *magnitude* and the value with respect to the origin and normal vector in the particle fields. This in particular is very useful if you want to see what happens at different values of Z (say below and above the galactic plane) for a disk object 

```
#!python

    def _particle_cylindrical_position_z(field, data):	
        normal = data.get_field_parameter('normal')
        center = data.get_field_parameter('center')
        bv = data.get_field_parameter("bulk_velocity")
	    pos = spos
        pos = YTArray([data[ptype, pos % ax] for ax in "xyz"])
        theta = get_cyl_theta(pos, center)
        z = get_cyl_z(pos, center)
        pos = pos - np.reshape(center, (3, 1))
        cylz = get_cyl_z_component(pos, normal)
        return cylz



    registry.add_field((ptype, "particle_cylindrical_position_z"),
              function=_particle_cylindrical_position_z,
              validators=[ValidateParameter("center"),
                          ValidateParameter("normal")],
              units="cm", particle_type = True)
   

    def _particle_cylindrical_z(field,data):
        normal = data.get_field_parameter("normal")
        coords = get_periodic_rvec(data)
        return data.ds.arr(get_cyl_z(coords,normal),
                          'code_length')

    registry.add_field((ptype, "particle_cylindrical_z"),
              function=_particle_cylindrical_z,
              validators=[ValidateParameter("normal"), ValidateParameter("center")],
              units="cm", particle_type = True)

```

The distinction is defined with the two functions in utils/maths_utils.py .. where we have get_cyl_r (magnitude) and get_cyl_r_componant (cylindrical radius with respect to the normal and the centre)

```
#!python


    def get_cyl_r(coords, normal):
        # The cross product of the normal (J) with a coordinate vector
        # gives a vector of magnitude equal to the cylindrical radius.
        res_normal = resize_vector(normal, coords)
        tile_shape = [1] + list(coords.shape)[1:]
        J = np.tile(res_normal, tile_shape)
        JcrossCoords = np.cross(J, coords, axisa=0, axisb=0, axisc=0)
        return np.sqrt(np.sum(JcrossCoords**2, axis=0))
     
    def get_cyl_r_component(vectors, theta, normal):
        # The r of a vector is the vector dotted with rhat
        (xprime, yprime, zprime) = get_ortho_basis(normal)
        res_xprime = resize_vector(xprime, vectors)
        res_yprime = resize_vector(yprime, vectors)
        tile_shape = [1] + list(vectors.shape)[1:]
        Jx = np.tile(res_xprime,tile_shape)
        Jy = np.tile(res_yprime,tile_shape)
        rhat = Jx*np.cos(theta) + Jy*np.sin(theta)
        return np.sum(vectors*rhat,axis=0)
```

Should we have similar fields for the fluid fields as well? Or should I leave that for another PR?
content.html:
Okey I have been having a play around with some of my own data and these new fields

Beforehand, YT has been computing the radius and height in slightly different ways for particles and fluids in spherical and cylindrical systems.

YT has just been computing the magnitude of the radius and the height in the gas, whilst plotting the radius and the height with respect to the origin and normal vector for the particle fields.

The new suggested changes below means we can access both the magnitude and the value with respect to the origin and normal vector in the particle fields. This in particular is very useful if you want to see what happens at different values of Z (say below and above the galactic plane) for a disk object 

    def _particle_cylindrical_position_z(field, data):  
        normal = data.get_field_parameter('normal')
        center = data.get_field_parameter('center')
        bv = data.get_field_parameter("bulk_velocity")
        pos = spos
        pos = YTArray([data[ptype, pos % ax] for ax in "xyz"])
        theta = get_cyl_theta(pos, center)
        z = get_cyl_z(pos, center)
        pos = pos - np.reshape(center, (3, 1))
        cylz = get_cyl_z_component(pos, normal)
        return cylz



    registry.add_field((ptype, "particle_cylindrical_position_z"),
              function=_particle_cylindrical_position_z,
              validators=[ValidateParameter("center"),
                          ValidateParameter("normal")],
              units="cm", particle_type = True)


    def _particle_cylindrical_z(field,data):
        normal = data.get_field_parameter("normal")
        coords = get_periodic_rvec(data)
        return data.ds.arr(get_cyl_z(coords,normal),
                          'code_length')

    registry.add_field((ptype, "particle_cylindrical_z"),
              function=_particle_cylindrical_z,
              validators=[ValidateParameter("normal"), ValidateParameter("center")],
              units="cm", particle_type = True)

The distinction is defined with the two functions in utils/maths_utils.py .. where we have get_cyl_r (magnitude) and get_cyl_r_componant (cylindrical radius with respect to the normal and the centre)

    def get_cyl_r(coords, normal):
        # The cross product of the normal (J) with a coordinate vector
        # gives a vector of magnitude equal to the cylindrical radius.
        res_normal = resize_vector(normal, coords)
        tile_shape = [1] + list(coords.shape)[1:]
        J = np.tile(res_normal, tile_shape)
        JcrossCoords = np.cross(J, coords, axisa=0, axisb=0, axisc=0)
        return np.sqrt(np.sum(JcrossCoords**2, axis=0))

    def get_cyl_r_component(vectors, theta, normal):
        # The r of a vector is the vector dotted with rhat
        (xprime, yprime, zprime) = get_ortho_basis(normal)
        res_xprime = resize_vector(xprime, vectors)
        res_yprime = resize_vector(yprime, vectors)
        tile_shape = [1] + list(vectors.shape)[1:]
        Jx = np.tile(res_xprime,tile_shape)
        Jy = np.tile(res_yprime,tile_shape)
        rhat = Jx*np.cos(theta) + Jy*np.sin(theta)
        return np.sum(vectors*rhat,axis=0)

Should we have similar fields for the fluid fields as well? Or should I leave that for another PR?

content.raw:
I think you made this patch on the wrong line.

Rather than using the bitbucket web editor, it would probably be best to edit the code on your local copy of yt.  That way you'll be able to do a minimal level of testing (importing the code, running a test script) before pushing up to bitbucket.  Let me know if you have any questions about running the yt tests.

content.raw:
particle_cylindrical_position_radius is pretty much a direct port of particle_spherical_position_radius. Which interestingly enough returns negative r values. particle_cylindrical_radius is more of an equivalent copy of the gas cylindrical_r calculation.

What I should also note is that when I was testing this out, I was getting slightly different values of the radius for both calculations ... I am willing to spend some time soon more thoughly looking over that, but feel free to look at it as well.
content.html:
particle_cylindrical_position_radius is pretty much a direct port of particle_spherical_position_radius. Which interestingly enough returns negative r values. particle_cylindrical_radius is more of an equivalent copy of the gas cylindrical_r calculation.

What I should also note is that when I was testing this out, I was getting slightly different values of the radius for both calculations ... I am willing to spend some time soon more thoughly looking over that, but feel free to look at it as well.

content.raw: Negative radii sounds like a bug to me.
content.html: Negative radii sounds like a bug to me.

content.raw:
I made particle_relative_position and particle_relative_velocity because I wanted to get the [xyz] coordinates of star particles relative to the centre of an abstract data object (e.g a disk) with an abstract normal vector (i.e the center of the object is [0,0,0] with a normal vector defining the z direction, with the x and y directions orthogonal to this vector).

I am happy to improve the clarity of this by adding more detail to the docstring if that would be useful.
content.html:
I made particle_relative_position and particle_relative_velocity because I wanted to get the [xyz] coordinates of star particles relative to the centre of an abstract data object (e.g a disk) with an abstract normal vector (i.e the center of the object is [0,0,0] with a normal vector defining the z direction, with the x and y directions orthogonal to this vector).

I am happy to improve the clarity of this by adding more detail to the docstring if that would be useful.

e.g


```

print sphere["particle_cylindrical_position_radius"].min()
```
returns a negative value

-6.41156882532e+23 cm

and 


```
#!python

print sphere["particle_spherical_position_radius"].min()
```
returns a negative value
-7.83826739716e+23 cm

content.raw: You're getting mesh positions here, not particle positions.  You should probably be using the same construction to create `coords` here as you use for `pos` in `_particle_cylindrical_radius`

content.raw:
I've fixed a number of issues with this pull request in [996bc5a](https://bitbucket.org/ngoldbaum/yt/commits/996bc5a04b09668415711c22c278b04163fa5c46) in my repo.  I decided that the best way to solve all the issues this PR has brought up is just to pull off the bandaid and do the field renaming now.  Since this PR adds new fields, I think they should go in with the names we want them to permanently have.

To this end, I've renamed all the fields with names like `particle_spherical_` fields to be `particle_position_spherical_`. Where these fields already exist inside yt, I've left a copy of the original field name and marked it for deprecation.  These fields will also now return results that are correct (notably, the `particle_spherical_` fields in the current version of yt are totally innacurate).  I've done this for the position and velocity fields.

In so doing, I noticed a bunch of bugs in the current version of the PR that have been fixed.

Take a look at the following notebook to visualize with the particle position fields look like: http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/ngoldbaum/e86250523d2ce2036669

The notebook uses a new function that I'm going to PR separately that makes it easy to add new deposited particle fields.

@cosmosquark I'm happy to take over shepherding a new PR that includes your changes and mine.  You can also pull from me and update this pull request or just reject my changes :)  If you go with the latter, maybe we should hash out what to do on the mailing list.
content.html:
I've fixed a number of issues with this pull request in 996bc5a in my repo. I decided that the best way to solve all the issues this PR has brought up is just to pull off the bandaid and do the field renaming now. Since this PR adds new fields, I think they should go in with the names we want them to permanently have.

To this end, I've renamed all the fields with names like particle_spherical_ fields to be particle_position_spherical_. Where these fields already exist inside yt, I've left a copy of the original field name and marked it for deprecation. These fields will also now return results that are correct (notably, the particle_spherical_ fields in the current version of yt are totally innacurate). I've done this for the position and velocity fields.

In so doing, I noticed a bunch of bugs in the current version of the PR that have been fixed.

Take a look at the following notebook to visualize with the particle position fields look like: http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/ngoldbaum/e86250523d2ce2036669

The notebook uses a new function that I'm going to PR separately that makes it easy to add new deposited particle fields.

Ben Thompson I'm happy to take over shepherding a new PR that includes your changes and mine. You can also pull from me and update this pull request or just reject my changes :) If you go with the latter, maybe we should hash out what to do on the mailing list.
